categories: Category:Articles with elements from unlicensed sources

nodes.text: Birthday cake was a cake served at a birthday. It was eaten at the birthday celebration of both the Ewoks Kneesaa a Jari Kintaka—where it was made with berries—and Shodu Warrick, where she was given the cake by the wokling Malani.
A birthday cake was a round cake eaten for an individual's birthday. It was edible by Ewoks. The cake could be made with berries and decorated with frosting.

At some point, at the grand birthday party of the Ewok Princess Kneesaa a Jari Kintaka on the Forest Moon of Endor, Kintaka's father, Chief Chirpa, planned on serving her a birthday cake. As he planned on making the cake with berries in it, he enlisted the help of two other Ewoks to help him pick berries from the trees. A pair of Duloks attempted to stop them and steal the berries, but Chirpa and the Ewoks were able to fend them off and return to the village. That night, Kintaka was served her birthday cake, which she considered to be lovely. The cake had several different colors of frosting and had her name written in High Galactic.

In 3 ABY, at the birthday party of the Ewok Shodu Warrick, the wokling Malani brought a birthday cake for Warrick—the first she had ever made. Warrick thanked the young Ewok and took a slice. As she ate the cake, Malani noted that it was her first; despite her difficulty in chewing and swallowing the slice, Shodu told Malani that she would have never guessed, and Malani beamed.
In 43 ABY, the Human Flitcher Poste jokingly warned the pilot Tobb Jadak that a laserfile he had hidden in a birthday cake might be found by the security officer at the prison on the planet Carcel.
Birthday cake first appeared in "A Gift for Shodu," an episode of the second season of the animated Ewoks series, which first aired on October 4, 1986.

Birthday cake was later pictured on the cover of a 1987 MyComyc reprint of all of the Ewoks and Star Wars: Droids comics, where it was being eaten by Wicket Warrick, C-3PO, Mickey Mouse, and several other non-Star Wars characters.

The non-canon comic "Lunch Break," which was written and illustrated by Jonathan Adams and published in Star Wars Tales 16 on June 25, 2003 featured birthday cake. In the comic, the cake is served and consumed at the birthday party of a stormtrooper of the Galactic Empire at some point between 0 ABY and 3 ABY.
